text: This is a spectacular museum with so much to recommend it I don't know where to start. The museum building outside and inside is incredibly beautiful. The medieval section has many beautiful pieces. I also enjoyed the China and Korea exhibit. That's all I had time to see! If you are in London don't miss this gem.

This museum has a very eclectic collection. The curators have done an amazing job. A pretty big building, and every floor and every room is very well organized, the descriptions are interesting and make connections between the environment.
There are big spaces with huge sculptures, and cosy rooms with very fine and small pieces.
The cast room and it's collection could be even a separate museum. It was beautiful, must to see.

The description of this museum (online) does not fully describe everything you will see here. It states textiles, fashion, etc. but it is so much more than that. The cast room alone is worth the visit, truly. We thought we would 'briefly' stop in to enjoy the museum, and ended up staying for many hours. Definitely worth seeing. This and the British Museum have been my favorites on this trip. Highly recommend.

Amazing place 🤩.  I love the atmosphere of this museum.  Beautiful interiors, stunning exhibitions and exhibits.  This is a very good place to de-stress, also spend a nice time with friends or family.  The museum is long, you can go back there many times and you will always find something new that will surprise or amaze you.  I highly recommend to everyone going to London!

This is my favorite museum in London. The exhibits are all so interesting. My favorites were the fashion, jewelry, and statue rooms. Also, Harry Styles' famous cardigan is here! Lastly, this gift shop was the best museum gift shop I have EVER been to! I highly, highly recommend it.

My favourite art museum in London! There is a mixture of modern and traditional pieces: a little something for everyone. I would recommend getting a map on entry, then deciding which sections and floors you want to see, as it is a very big museum. It wasn't busy when we went, however it might be in public holidays, so be careful.

If you are in London and like beautiful things this is the place for you.  Everything from ancient mosaics to Victorian teacups is here in this huge and beautiful museum.  Paintings, sculpture, ceramics, clothing and other categories to numerous to mention, from around the world: it is all at the V&A.  All amenities including a nice cafe are on site.  Very close to two tube stations and in a lovely area, it is also next door to the Natural History Museum, and lots of places for upscale shopping and food.

A great place to visit for all the family. There are various exhibitions to entertain and really wonderful to see a dance session which children could take part in, without a booking.

The museum has numerous galleries from famous gowns to modern creations (like Harry Styles cardigan) to paintings from different eras.
Their copies of originals such as that of Michelangelo's David are impressive to say the least.

Well worth the visit especially with the family as some of the objects can be interacted with-try tying a caveat or creating your own monogram.

Absolutely a must do in London. It is hard to explain the feeling one gets when entering each part of the Victoria and Albert Museum. There is a lovely cafe if you need to get something to drink or eat so don’t stress.

Easy place to spend hour after hour after hour in and when driving home wonder if we should go back again tomorrow or next week

The building from the outside is stunning as well. I recommend going on a Sunday as it wasn’t busy.

Below scores are out of 10
Customer Service   10
Atmosphere  10
Presentation   10
Location   10
Overall  10

I Attended a rather spectacular Faberge event here, which was truly remarkable. The food, the ambiance, the historical building including the Faberge event set up, made for an outstanding evening, that I will not forget.

Although this is renowned for being a museum. I have been here on several occasions for luxury brand events, each one better then the last.

Worth the visit if in London, the building is full of historical wonders. Should you attend an event, you are in for a treat. The V and A have a keen eye for detail alongside superior knowledgeable staff… what a remarkable museum!

Simply amazing.

Better for adults than children.
A great free museum for adults to expand your knowledge & feed your curiosity with activities for children including hands on ceramics (advanced booking) interactive theatre displays with dress-up, Capability Brown tours and so much more!

The cafes feel special too albeit only Benugo - live piano music inside and sitting in the central courtyard is wonderful on a nice day (with a paddle in the fountain!)

Sadly one of the security guards was so harsh in manner towards my nephew when he reached out to touch a (well touched) bronze lion he will no longer to go to the V&A

Wonderful museum and one of my favourite places! Beautiful space that is full of amazing art and artifacts. Perfect for families, with accessible spaces and lots to see. Be certain to spend time in the Middle Eastern section, which offers many surprising pieces of art that many westerners aren't exposed to. Unfortunately, very little information on the impacts of colonialism or imperialism is addressed in the displays, which should be taken into consideration.

Amazing museum, with a very eclectic collection of sculpture and creative arts from about 300 AD to present day. The ceramics exhibit is astonishing, though Old World centered. Similarly, they have a glass exhibit that is phenomenal. The Cast Rooms are really interesting as well.

Amazing collection of art objects of all sorts. Paintings,  sculptures, stunning tableware.
Beautifully laid out with a wonderful set of food, drink, and coffee options.
Relaxing and lovely courtyard space with a wading pool.

Some brilliant rooms - the cast rooms with replicas of the statue of David and other enormous jaw dropping sculptures and statues and monuments - it was worth coming for these alone. The jewellery room was also fantastic and so was the new Design exhibit. The Buddhism / Japan / Korea rooms didn’t wow me - felt stale, just walls of items in glass cabinets. Also Buddhism was located next to the entrance so was extremely noisy. The shop could be improved, the range wasn’t amazing. They only had items relating to certain exhibitions. I love gift shops and I didn’t buy a single thing. Worth a visit to this museum along with the National history museum next door.

This is my favorite museum by far! The building is beautiful inside and out. Thoroughly enjoyed wondering around and checking out just the architecture. There’s so much to see here. I would highly recommend. It’s a must see.

Wonderful place, and free. Whatever your interest there is a wing you will get lost in. Over 6 football pitches of beautifully curated items. Be prepared to do a lot of walking, up and down stairs; it is a glorious warren. The staff were always around to give directions and advice.
On a nice day the garden is the perfect place to have a coffee and a snack.
One of the best museums in town. You need at least half a day. Museum shop is really good. A lot of unique and beautiful materials. The garden is fantastic. Open sky, grass but inside the museum.

The V & A always a great place to visit and visit again!!! They have shows, tours and focused viewings. The staff are helpful as its easy to get lost if going to see a specific era or artist, being such a vast museum. Definitely happily spend the day there. If you have a busy lifestyle it's a great way to relax on a day off, it is a go to 'must' at least once!

Loved this Museum.
Great collections of art from around the world.
It has Tipu Sultan Loin attacking a soldier & creating noises/ music as well in south east / Indian gallery area.
No ticket needed & donations are accepted.
Photography is allowed.
Highly recommended & must visit museum during UK 🇬🇧 visit.

The V&A has a stunning collection within a beautiful building. The current exhibit “fashioning masculinity” is well worth a visit though £20 entry is a bit steep for what it is (comparing to special exhibitions in other museums around the world). The gardens and cafe are lovely.

Amazing museum to visit. A perfect place for a person who loves art, takes the time to read, has the knowledge about art or wants to learn about it. There are so many different pieces of art to see, so take your time. Even better, spend a whole day there.

Just a great place with a wide range of humanities finest examples of craftsmanship. It is genuinely incredible what we have managed to achieve. I am an atheist, but if anything good came from the brain dysfunction that is religion you would struggle to argue that it motivated people to produce incredible works of art that would have been a lesser version of themselves if the artist hadn't been motivated by their faith. From ironmongery to clothing and everything in between. If you haven't been you owe it to yourself to saturate your brain with what it has to offer at least once in your life.

Gorgeous museum, must do. Much better and more exhibits than the natural history one.
They have clothes, furniture and objects ranging from all over the globe and different time periods abd they have clothes on display!
I highly recommend. You can easily walk around for 3 hrs.

I took photos inside of the less noticed lines and dots and sketches if you will; the bones of the beautiful building. That being said the variety and astounding vast charm of this versatile museum are not to be understated. Do not hesitate to explore upper levels and back channels and cubby’s and so on. We found so much more when we explored the building. From art, to jewels, iron works, photography, fashion, facades, periods, dynasty’s and so on. An exceptional museum to say the very least. A VERY good way to spend a rainy day.

The most Wonderful Museum ever, i went there twice for at least several hours each time and it was not enough time. Be prepared to be amazed, and get ready to walk about for hours whenever you can take a break at one of the 3 tea saloons. They are beautiful and the tea goes perfect with some scones or muffins. As a recommendation start from at ground 0 and walk your way up. Trust me when i tell you, you'll be pleasantly amazed about the different galleries and abundance of displays. From underwater until the space, everything is in this museum. So take your sweet time, enjoy and be wondered at every step. Check the jewerls gallery and the gold ans silver galleries, my favorites

This is my favourite museum of all times!! If you truly want to immerse yourself in the experience of V&A, I recommend at least 5-6 hours! Very interesting exhibitions. It is a must see if you are in London!!

Whenever I have a little spare time I visit the V&A one of London's best museums.  Today I enjoyed the Cast Court which is in two adjacent enormous rooms.  Fortunately during the Victorian era casts were taken of various religious buildings and statues.  For some of the statues they are the only ones left due to bomb damage such as the Temple Church in London.

Outstanding museum. Great variety of art, artifacts, sculptures, jewelry, and history. Middle Eastern, Asian, European and other worldwide artifacts. And don't miss the cafe when you get hungry.  And all this, for FREE!

Best place to understand a little bit of history and culture about various lineage around the world. David sculpture is so much massive than I expected, and the story about the artist and the statue was incredible. It's good to go with children, as it ignites the curiosity to learn about the monuments present here. Quiet and calm place best fit to go with a group of friends who have the same wavelength to get to know something new.
It's my first visit here, and I felt that one full day is not enough to get to know everything presented here! Still decently managed to visit various sectors in this place.

Favourite museum from far. A must-visit if you are like me and like to explore and get lost in museum. It’s stunning and you never have enough time to see everything! I usually stay for a full day as you can eat nicely inside. If you can try to go during week days otherwise it gets pretty busy

This museum was quite enjoyable! With artifacts from all over, helpful staff who gave great context to displays to make it even more engaging, and an enormous Cast Court (next best thing to seeing some of the most famous sculptures in the world!), I'm so glad we included this in our itinerary!

We had a spectacular experience at the V&A museum. I especially liked the cast hall and Raphael cartoons.

There are far too many exhibitions to fit into one day, best to time box yourself and make multiple trips.

SO much to see and much bigger than expected! The sheer amount of exhibits can honestly be somewhat overwhelming at times. Excellent for students and if you want to learn about art/history in general as they also explain some techniques. I'd recommend you take one or two of the guided tours for some more information and "fun facts" about various pieces.

Spent a large part of the day here and still did not complete it.  The size scale of some of the exhibits are amazing.  Plenty of different things to see.  It's slightly quieter that the surrounding museums.

Fantastic museum visited on a Monday and walked straight in though the South Kensington underground entrance just follow the signs  - no queues.....absolutely loads to see huge museum bright and airy... Cafe is a little pricey but as admission is free I can live with that. You won't get many days out this good with free entry for all. Well done V&A.

The world's largest museum of Decorative arts and design with a permanent collection of over 4.5 million. Named in honour of Prince Albert and Queen Victoria, it was founded in 1852 and has grown to cover 0.05 square kilometres and 145 galleries. It collects 5,000 years of art, from ancient times to the present, from every continent, from European, North American, Asian and North African cultures. The museum is a non-governmental sector public institution composed of ministries of culture, media and sport. The collection of ceramics, glass, textiles, clothing, silver, iron, jewellery, furniture, medieval antiquities, sculpture, prints and prints, drawings and photographs is the largest and most comprehensive of the world. The museum houses the world's largest collection of post-classical sculpture, and the group's largest project of the Italian Renaissance is outside Italy. The department includes Asian art from South Asia, China, Japan, Korea and the Islamic world.

An incredible museum with a hugely varied selection of exhibitions. From the dawn of known human history to contemporary design collections, there is something for everyone inside the beautifully designed and organized building. Must visit for museum lovers when in London.

The V&A is such a unique museum. It has some exhibitions you can pay to see as well as the rest of the museum you can walk around for free. There is nothing ordinary about the V&A everything is extraordinary and beautiful. Additionally the Natural History museum is opposite to it. If you fancy seeing a different variety of artifacts collected.  Both are worth the visit and experience they provide.

I have visited the V and A many times in the last 60 years. It holds a fascinating amount of objects and now when I take friends and family it is great finding things they want to see! Glad to be out again after isolating.  Also fab cafe and check out the carvings on pillars and outside on the carved window edges. Beautiful place so much still to see!

When a museum has an entire section on locks - locks! - you know you're going to be amazed. We loved the fashion, cast rooms, cartoons, English history, Japan... it doesn't end. There are rooms with five things that would be centerpieces of most other museums. The Beatrix Potter exhibit is very nice, as long as you don't mind the constant sound of scurrying mice (added and amplified for effect). If you do, well, good luck.

This is my all-time favorite museum, so I will go at least once or twice every time I visit London, which is easy since it's free. This time, I went to a paid exhibit about Faberge, which was excellent. It's way too big to see all in one visit, so I suggest you plan ahead to see whichever parts interest you most.

I always see at least the fashion and jewelry exhibits. The Cafe is exquisite, but the food is not very good. I've only managed to snag a table inside once.

The V&A is really a must-see when visiting London.

Definitely one of the best museums I have visited.  Alot lot to see. I will say, if you want to really enjoy here than atleast 1 full day. Exhibitions are wonderful,  and amazing. Building itself is amazing to watch from outside and inside.  Add it to bucket list.  Entry is free, no advance booking.  One suggestion,  plan your day for it.

I marked V&A as my must go museum in London. Actually I went there twice and my daughter who registered under 26 membership went there three times within a month. The exhibitions are so impressive and I you must save three days to complete them. We enjoyed the coffee and scones, the beautiful flowers and pool in the garden and met our friends at the Cafe and had our afternoon tea at the Members’ Room. Roman, the gentleman greeted us at the M Room is so kind and we promised to come back often. I also bought souvenirs from the shop for my friends in Canada!

Lovely place to spend a day! Lot's of food near by! Station (south Kensington) very close by. Pubs within walking distance. Picnic spots available on the lawn! Dog friendly. Security gaurds in the lawn too. Would recommend. Free to roam, donations welcome.

text:
Free to enter, but they make up for it in the cafe and the gift shop!

Overall a wondrous place; could easily spend 3hrs minimum here.

The British comedy history was interesting on what defines us as British.

The V&A is the most wonderful museum to visit. It is free to visit most of the exhibits and rooms.
At the weekends it is crowded but that doesn't deter from the lovely visit.
There is so much to see and do you can easily spend a whole day here. Even sitting outside on the courtyard admiring the architecture is great, whilst sipping a cup of tea.
I have been to this museum so many times, and each time I see something different that I previously missed.
I'm never get bored with the V&A.

I was pleasantly surprised by this museum as it is not really one of the premier museums in London but it has to be one the best to visit as a tourist and a regular Londoner. The exhibits were great, so diverse and vast. The lighting was amazing and the background to each hall was so mesmerising. If you are in London, I would definitely recommend going to this museum!

Visited the Alice in Wonderland show a couple of months ago, and was very impressed by this museum. The show was beautiful though short, and we did walked about a bit through the first floor to see some of the artwork. Hope to return in my next trip to London for a longer visit.

Free museum so didn't have time to see paid for exhibitions as plenty to keep us busy. Loved women's fashion, Asian sections. Sculptures were brilliant. Here couple of hours. Loved the V and A souvenir book at only £3.00 and brilliant value and in different front covers for different languages. Highly recommended

The Victoria and Albert Museum or V&A Museum located in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea in London is the world's largest museum of applied arts,
decorative arts and design, housing a permanent collection of over 2.27 million objects. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The V&A covers 12.5 acres and 145 galleries. Its collection spans 5000 years of art, from
ancient times to the present day, from the cultures of Europe, North America, Asia and North Africa. It is worth a visit!

Wanted to see Beatrix Potter exhibition but didn't realise it was half term down south so fully booked 🤔 it's far too big to see everything in 1 visit so probably best to pick a couple of floors or exhibits you're interested in. Signage is not that good and loads of people were having to ask staff directions so good job there are plenty of them. Cafe is fine but real selling point is the fabulous surroundings see photos

To the V&A to see the 'Alice In Wonderland' Exhibition. I adore the V&A, it is one of my favourite spaces in London. Although the AIW exhibition has an additional cost, it is perfectly possible to spend a day here for free, there is lots to see without spending any cash. The building itself is glorious, there is not many better ways to spend an afternoon than enjoying a coffee in the courtyard on a sunny day. The staff are knowledgeable and friendly, there is a gorgeous tearoom selling an array of hot drinks and (pricey) homebakes. If you are visiting London, do try and put this place on your list :)

Lacklustre male fashion exhibition. Considering men's fashion is underdeveloped to begin with, this exhibition only just begins to explore the scope of masculine fashion - not only does it barely explore the future of male fashion beyond some extremely mainstream examples at the very end of the show (infact we attended the graduate fashion show the next day which already explored much more interesting concepts in male fashion), but even it's retrospective was surface level at best and as a whole was unimaginatively presented.

Of course the rest of the museums permanent exhibits are great and truly of a world class standard, but my review reflects my first time attending a paid exhibition here, and it was not worth the money.

In addition to this, the cafe was quite expensive for drinks and you have to serve your own table (if you ask me, it should be one or the other, not both), so when visiting with family it means someone (me) roundtripping between the cafe counter and our table as the drinks became ready. Also the tables/chairs are ugly compared to the beauty of the tea room itself, as well as there being too many tables for the space, so it seemed crowded and much cheaper feeling than it should be.

This museum is very beutiful with a pleasant patio in the middle of it. The collection is very good, specially the clothes and statues. That was my second visit and I would go again. It is located just across the street from the Natural History Museum.

This was my first visit to this museum, a sad admission indeed!  I had always thought it was just a fashion and design museum and therefore of limited interest but how wrong I was!  We spent the afternoon here and I could easily return and do the same tomorrow.  And probably the next day too.
There is just so much there that I wasn't expecting and we only covered the medieval, south asian and Islamic sections.  The museum is well laid out and there is plenty of seating if you need to sit and absorb things.  The information boards are also very good, both for individual items and the topic as a whole although that being said it is sometimes unclear which item the board is referring too as they aren't numbered.
The cafe is also good and has a nice variety of lunch and snack offerings.  This is now my second favourite place after the British Museum (the V&A that is, not the cafe!).

So much to see - from the displays to the architecture itself. Summer meant kids were free to play in the fountain at the middle court. Don’t miss lunch at the cafeteria, because there’s always an exciting selection of cooked food with salads you can choose. Everything is delicious.

Tremendous amount of art! Could easily spend a week there! Our family spent an hour there looking at the fashions through the ages,  the jewelry and crowns on display  - beautiful! The cost is donations to them solvent! With the trip!

Incredible experience. The museum went above and beyond our expectations starting at the entrance which is free to all and there is no line for entry. The variety of art in the museum made finding a section that fit our tastes easy and wanting come back for more especially the male fashion exhibit that just opened. Highly recommend.(One last little surprise in the museum was a dance performance in the courtyard pool)
The Victoria and Albert museum is one of my favourite places to visit. Not what you might expect. So much history and different exciting culture brought to life. Definitely worth seeing .
A great museum! Worth a visit, free entrance (as most in London), interesting exposition. Don't forget to visit the cool and design & crafts filled gift shop.

There is always so much to see at the V&A Museum, most of the exhibitions are free but are there exhibitions you have to pay to see but I can assure you they are worth it. Fantastic collections to enjoy, there is always so much too see and enjoy. In my opinion is the best museum of London.

The English history section is good with very relevant artifacts to the Tudor era, and a few nice Renaissance sculptures and medieval clerical artifacts as well. Where this museum let me down was with how many replicas there were. The replica Trajan's column is impressive, but it is a replica and should not be paraded as a centerpiece.

I've been twice in the last month. Once to the general collection, and then to the exhibition 'Fashioning Masculinities'. It's free to enter for the general displays though it's cool to donate something towards upkeep. You have to pay for the special exhibitions and it's best to get tickets in advance, their website is easy to use to buy them. This is one of my favourite museums and I see something different every time I go.

Really nice museum, I just think that it’s a pity that a lot of the stuff there is a replica. The outside garden is so enjoyable when it’s sunny, and the best place to take a break when you visit the museum, or just go there to spend the time reading a book for example. One of the things I like the most about V&A is the Late thematic Nights, every last Friday of each months (with some exceptions) when there’s music, workshops, performances until 10pm. I went there this last Friday and it was a really great time, they also have a bar and a dj, pretty cool initiative!!

This museum is an absolute gem! I would return to London to spend many more hours here. There’s definitely more to see than I had time for, but I truly enjoyed everything I saw including the Roman sculptures, fashion, jewelry, John Constable landscapes, Rafael cartoons, and stained glass. And the café is phenomenal, as many people mentioned. The food was incredible, with many options, teas and coffee. I thought it was really interesting that my sister went to the Natural History Museum next-door, which she said was incredible, but also very crowded with lots of groups of school kids.  She said that  made the Natural History Museum noisy and a bit chaotic, so if you want a more adult experience, the Victoria & Albert museum is a great choice!

It's a place of knowledge, loads to see, much to learn and understand. All ancient history of all regions of the world is nicely preserved . Religions to understand. Must visit place. Free entry so no tickets atall.. the cafeteria inside is simply beautiful. Needs atleast 3 hrs minimum.
This museum is such a wonderful collection of eclectic item's. One of my favourites  I've never managed to get all the way around. Always so much to see.

I enjoyed this museum a lot more than I thought I would. There is some amazing architecture on display - one that stood out above the rest is an ancient Roman column that's size and detail is hard to comprehend. There is an pretty cool display of old locks and keys, and the display of ancient jewelry is also worth checking out.

Great museum, free entry with suggested donation. It's a huuuuge space with something for everyone. Plenty of interactive areas and opportunity to do drawings and the like.  The jewellery section is amazing and well worth 30 mins to get round.  Lovely cafe in the garden run by benugo offering sandwiches and salads. Hot drinks and cakes.

Just amazing. Not usually my thing (I'd normally head over the road the the natural history museum) but I |ally enjoyed it. So much to see. Focus on a small area and enjoy it is my advice. Good cafe, nice place to sit and eat outside if you bring your own food.

Absolutely wonderful place from the scars the blitz to the amazing exhibits inside, we were told to allow 2-3 hours but over the 2 days we spent 7.5 hours and there's still more to see. It's worth it though we'll definitely be coming back soon.

As a connoisseur of museums I found that this particular museum is one of the best I have ever come across. It has organized all its pieces very carefully and is a pleasant walk-through. I highly recommend this museum above the others.
Incredible place to visit, huge collection, so much to explore, learn or just refresh history lesson. Would advice to allow at least few days to cover all the floors and exhibitions.
V&A has a great collection of art and culture. Been there many times, recently last Friday, never felt I had enough. Definitely must a visit place in London.
Beautiful Museum with so much treasures stored here. The Victoria and Albert museum is free so you have no excuse not to go. It’s a real treat to walk these halls of history.

I found the museum to be a bit of a bore. The sculpture exhibit was beautiful, but the fashion part was very mediocre and quite run of the mill. I expected much more from such a famous museum that is so well known for this.

Maybe this was just us, but I booked entry tickets ahead of time and when we came in there was no one to check. Could have saved the trouble of ordering tickets 😂

Lastly, Cafe is very over crowded. Could definitely use more staff during rush hour

I wasn’t expecting much from this museum I don’t know why I thought that but i’d say it’s the best museum i’ve ever been to! I couldn’t believe the amount of stuff they had on display, the amount of history was overwhelming, you could spend all day here and still not see everything! A truly great museum!
Absolutely love this place. I visit every time I'm in London. It's toppers with such beautiful objects, a breathtaking display of human artistic and creative endeavour!

Museums in London are free. Special exhibits have a fee. If you’re not super interested in the exhibit that is there during your visit, don’t feel you’ll miss out on something spectacular if you don’t see it. The museum is full of spectacular, amazing things at every turn and almost impossible to absorb and see everything during one visit. Also the staff are super helpful and kind. Great place to spend the day!

Loved going to this museum.  Despite the fact I had little time, I made the most of it.  I was particularly impressed with the Jewelry section and the crown of Queen Victoria which had such beauty and emotional value to her and her husband Albert.
Wonderfully eclectic range of designs from multiple cultures. Take an afternoon to explore. Best of all it's completely free!

love the atmosphere of this museum.  Such beautiful interiors with stunning exhibitions and so many exhibits to see. You can visit here many times and will always find something of interest or a new exhibition to go see.
Very cool museum to check out! There are some really cool pieces of art in this museum. There is some cast work that has been done that is insanely impressive!

Extremely beautiful Museum and definitely worth a visit, actually my favourite museum in London. Besides the amazing collections inside the museum I liked the garden café the best, so relaxing to just sit in the garden with a cup of coffee.
Enourmous collection of beautiful objects from every corner of the world. One visit is definitely not enough. The museum is free. Do not miss the room with Raphael's cartoons.

One of London’s finest museums with a permanent collection and amazing seasonal exhibitions.
The building is just stunning and each one of the ballrooms is more beautiful than the other. The courtyard is a great place to chill and soak up some sun on a beautiful day
The best classical art museum I've been to, they have sections from all sorts of places and times. I would recommend planning for a visit to take about 3-4 hrs at minimum to view all galleries

If you want to understand world culture through the ages then the V&A is for you.  It has incredible statues of all sizes including a life size David extravagant Pulpits, tombs and more.  Fashion, living spaces, crafts, artifacts and more from around the globe.  In addition there is always an exhibition present for you to experience.

One of the most knowledgeable, sophisticated and historically rich places for the tourists.

This museum seems like a place from inside and contains antiques for Sicnic, Japanese, Arab (Mamluk, Andalusian), Turkic (Ottoman, Mongol), Indian (specifically mughal) and European civilisations, situated in places depicting the art of their time. The museum also has paintings and sculptures depicting indian, french, roman and greek legends of history.

You don't need a time machine to have a taste of different civilisations, this place will let you time travel through centuries.

On weekends the lights are switched on for all the antiques which allow to have a clear look, so I recommend visiting on weekends.

The navegation through the museum it was a little confuse to me, furthermore it is a really special collection with a lot of history and art.
I really liked the Japan part, even wasnt a big one.

The statues part has some different things to see and i still was impressed, considering that i alerady visited the british museum at the time.

The backyard garden is lovely and you can take a sit, rest a bit, enjoy the view and the sun!

Pretty much all museums get 5 stars from me, especially ones in London as so many of them are totally free. But the architecture section on the third floor sealed the deal. I only made it through 20%? of the collection in four-ish hours, so you'll need a good few days but it's free! So visit as often as you need to. And the interactive elements of this museum set it apart. All the quizzes and little activities keep things fresh and really help all the info sink in more. Soooo worth multiple visits honestly.

This is one of the must-visit museums in London. You get an amazing and huge collection of art and design pieces. Feast your eyes on art pieces not just from Europe and UK but also a smaller collection of art from Japan and Korea.
The museum was amazing. We loved the sculptures the history and the Fabergè collection. We enjoyed our visit and would love to go back again.

Very good place. Lots of things to see.
You need to go. You can store luggage.
You can enter without no charge

Every visitor of London should bring a visit to this magnificent museum for at least half a day and every Londoner is very lucky to be able to come several times. I spent more than one day, including a guided tour (all free 😀) and still I have not seen all of the huge collection full of surprising historical objects.
Do not forget to visit the restaurant which has also beautiful decorated rooms. The museum is extra friendly to childern, who can play in the garden with a little pool. Holes in the wall on the outside along Exhibition road conmemorate Second World War, when the museum stayed open to offer every Londoner some beauty.

The museum itself is a work of art. As we queued up to go inside, we admired the sculpted arches, columns, and window areas. It's notable that bombing damage from WWII has been preserved to show how close the museum came to being obliterated during the war, but I also think it's remarkable how often the Axis and Allies explicitly avoided destroying their enemies' cultural treasures.

There is far too much inside the museum to take in, just in a single visit. We focused mostly on the medieval and Renaissance galleries, but there is much, much more to see.

I think the most intriguing displays to me as an artist were the Cast Courts, which held casts or molds taken from original artworks (such as Trajan's Column in Rome, or Michealangelo's David) during the Victorian Era. These were brought back to England for artists to study, but also to help shape public tastes (for exple, so that the public could see what the real thing looked like and be more discerning in their artistic choices).

We also enjoyed examining Leighton's murals on Peace and on War.

It was a joy wandering around, I especially enjoyed the cartoons by Raphael and the cast courts, which are packed full of the most amazing monuments and sculptures. I will definitely be going back as I couldn't take it all in within one visit!

Free entry (but please make a donation) to a wonderful Victorian building instigated by Prince Albert. Massive collection - you could easily spend the whole day in this museum - reasonably priced café with seatin inside and outside in the beautiful quadrangle. Handbag exhibition on at the moment for a fee. Great jewellery section and fabulous 18 Rodin sculptures/bronzes. The cast section is impressive - has a cast of Trojan's column! A must visit section of the museum.

This is one of the finest museums in the world. Excellently displayed objects, great special exhibitions and incredibly variety.

The building itself is very photogenic and although it can be a bit of a maze the staff are friendly, helpful and can quickly point you where you need to go.

The cafes are beautiful and serve delicious food and drink. More suitable for adults it is one of London’s (and the UK’s) most fabulous attractions.
A huge museum. Be prepared to spend a few hours there roaming the artistic halls.

Great museum, some very interesting metalworks and beautiful jewellery and fashion from all around the world. Lovely garden to relax in too. Takes some time to walk around! I would like to visit again.

One of the city’s best museums. The secret is that areas of it can often be either empty or not busy at all. It’s a nice respite from the bonkers Natural History Museum. The medieval exhibits at V&A in particular are wonderful and rarely busy.
A great variety of exhibits in a beatiful building. The staff make sure one leaves before the closing time 😁

The museum was amazing! So many beautiful pieces of art and so many rooms. I could have stayed there for hours. The cafés serve a variety of different food and drinks and I'm sure even young kids wouldn't be bored at this museum because there's so much to see!
Always enjoy myself here - there's so much to see, there's something for everyone. Highlights for me were Alice: Curiouser and Curiouser, and Fashion.

Best museum in London. It's crazy that it is free to enter this amazing museum, do not overlook this place for other possibly more famous museums. It is most definitely worth a visit. If it's sunny enjoy the weather in the courtyard with a tea and a slice of cake
Still must book a timed ticket. Coat room was closed (early Dec 2021). But that was ok because the museum was really cold.

My wife and I absolutely loved our visit. The exhibits are fascinating, awe-inspiring and cover the history of very diverse regions of the world. It probably needs at least 2 visits to see most of the exhibits. And all of this for free entry, although donations are welcomed.
Fabulous place, visited Alice Curiosor and Curiosor exhibition but could have spent all there looking around the rest of the museum.

One of the free things to do in London, do book your advance tickets. Quite few sections were closed and was accessable for members only. But for free it was still worth a visit. Oh one thing, do have a coffee in cafe it will give you Royal Vibes lol
Amazing collection of Raphael paintings and the cast room is unmissable. We didn’t have time to see the rest of this amazing place.

I really enjoyed the V&A… seeing all the people mill about the exhibits and basking in the glorious sunlight outside made me feel so happy ☺️ my favourite exhibit was ‘1900–Now’… If only it had been a little bit bigger! 🤭 also, rapid response collecting is a really cool collections development strategy! 😲 I think I will read more about it (rapid response collecting, that is) on my own time!
Beautiful place. Shame the cloak room isn't operational. I was left carrying my winter coat, scarf and hat with me the whole time.
Best Museum in London! The permanent collections and exhibitions are fantastic, the gift shop is fab and the cafe is stunning. A great place to visit.
We LOVED this museum.  There's a truly incredible amount of content in these exhibits -- plan to spend several hours here at a minimum.
So this was surprising so many collections from different countries and times,so many artifacts 😱 but most surprising thing was they call it Lending or Gifting but we all know 😅😁 What that means.

Fantastic museum with amazing collections - and free. One possible area of improvement is making the place easier to navigate via a one-directional recommended path. The building is huge and confusing otherwise. Paper maps might be a way to implement this - there also might me systems already in place that I didn’t notice. There is so much to see!! An hour is not nearly enough.

Fantastic museum for art and architecture lovers. Vast collections from all over the world arranged by area and time of creation. All situated in beautiful building that is a real piece of art itself.
Free admission to regular collections and many seasonal exhibitions to choose from (paid extra).
In the summer most parts of the building stay cool which is great after a ride in tropical-like underground.
In the winter you can avoid cold by using the tunnel connecting the museum directly with the nearby South Kensington tube station.
Good choice of souvenirs in museum shop in reasonable prices compared to most of London museums. Very elegant restaurant is located on ground floor, as well as indoor and outdoor cafés.
Very nice museum. Something for everyone. I was very pleased with the Beatrix Potter display.
Went to see the Beatrix Potter exhibit - well worth it and had a lovely snack outside afterwards in the sunny courtyard. The V&A never disappoints!
What an amazing free museum. Totally worth your look .

Many interesting sculptures and other stuff, have to get a ticket before  going in as their corona procedure which you can get on their website  or thru their bar code infront of the museum the ticket is for free.

A powerful reminder that for centuries the human race, across cultures and civilisations, has produced countless masters in their craft- towering visionaries who created works of sublime intricacy and beauty, conceived, shaped and completed by the power of their unique aesthetic vision.

Contrast with our modern culture, where talentless hacks and insufferably precocious teens tweet and tiktok their vapid opinions into the great toilet of the world wide web. Even worse, those people who believe they have a seat at the table with history's creative elite simply because they can string a few adjectives together in a Google maps review.

Everything is vanity, saith the teacher.

Amazing just go. Weather permitting have coffee and cake in the central garden with the pool to soak up the atmosphere. Pricey of course as in all of these places but not forgetting it is free entrance which more than makes up for it. I always make a donation too.

I only saw a very small part of the museum but there is something of interest for all I feel. I look forward to visiting again to see more.

It is convenient to get to via the tube and is near other museums if you wish to vary your day out.
Worth the visit. Spectacular articles, paintings and sculptures from every continent

Definitely wear comfortable shoes, plenty of walking and so much to see.

The examples of fashion through the ages are brilliant, the difference in clothing and the materials and colours used are fascinating.

Suits of armour, stone work and some incredible iron work too.

Didn't get to explore the whole place so will return.
An amazing museum with almost too much to see. Best to focus on a couple of areas to get most from visit.
Stolen relics that were 'gifted' during the British Empire era should be returned.
Great collections! Make sure you visit the courtyard
A very big museum and a lot of cool things to see. I would recommend that you spend a day here if you want to see everything and not be rushed. The food was also pretty good too.

Visited recently for the Africa Fashion exhibition and had a great visit. Fantastic exhibition and good free displays too. There are plenty of facilities and the staff were really helpful.

The only down side was that the cafe was really busy and confusing and it wasn’t clear whether there were vegan options, so I left to eat somewhere else.

There was nothing interesting in the museum.I think people say they like museums to be cool , when in actual fact they are so boring and a waste of your time and you could be doing so much more woth your time then walking around aimlessly through a museum.☺️
Was so fun. There is so much to see. I need to visit again soon. Lots for kids to do and see too

This museum is so beautiful and the staff are so courteous and helpful. Saw the Africa fashion exhibit which was incredible especially the televised catwalk show at the start.  My only quibble is the cafe, the food is overpriced and the portions have shrunk since pre pandemic times.  I guess there is a need to recoup losses but it does mean only 4 stars.

A great afternoon out.  We went to their Bag exhibition and it was an incredibly in depth look into the fashion, design and creating the well known accessory.

As the heavens opened we stayed in and walked round the museum a bit and there is so much that we could have spent a whole afternoon in there.  Aiming to go back soon.

Wasn’t too busy on a Friday afternoon. There’s honestly so much to see there. It gets tiring after a way. Plan out what you want to see and walk accordingly, you can easily spend 2-3 hours there. So many great pieces of art and design.

We were here three years ago and thrilled with our food options while gluten free plus egg and shellfish allergy. This time around, our pre-lunch choices were practically non-existent, there was a gluten free brownie and a vegan cake, but nothing was both, except a bag of chips/crisps. Once hot food was served, there was much more available. We enjoyed the exhibits although sometimes I had difficulty determining which item each description belonged to.
Interesting exhibits, especially good if you're interested in asian exhibits or sculptures/casts.

So much to see.  Fascinating.
Lovely courtyard coffee area
At first I wasn't that into it, THEN I DIDN'T WANTED TO LEAVE! Every collection is incredible, do not miss it.

A favourite place to go and see in London! One visit is never enough, to many historical things to see, lots of inspiration if you are into the arts and history, has the best gift shop to buy loved ones something inspiring. A great cafe with lots to choose from and a lovely garden to sit out and have coffee.

It's a great museum for different religions paths and feelings you want to follow. It's a very underrated place. They only charge for special occasions when they host different cultures like gamers. Everything else is free and I'd highly recommend it to any artistic person or anyone looking for a day out

Always a delight.  Free entrance No booking or having to give email address to get in. If you want to see a special exhibition then you will need to book ahead, these cost extra.  Peaceful with plenty of room to look at items. Has to be my favourite museum in London.  Food a bit pricey but you can come and go  to eat elsewhere or take a pack lunch if the weather is good and sit by paddling pool. Some of the top floor exhibits are very interesting but it can be hard to find the stairs to the top floors so consult the floor plan. My favourite item is the fashion through the ages exhibition on the ground floor.

I love this museum. I haven’t been here since before COVID lockdown and it is as amazing as before. You can never get tired of exploring and learning about all the exhibits here.

There are slight changes to getting in.
Even though mainly the museum is free (this is why I love the London, where they make art and museums free so everyone can enjoy and experience great pieces of art), you have to book a timed ticket to enter.
Just go on the website and choose a suitable time and date (I do miss just turning up and explore, but hopefully we can do that soon again).
And turn up about 15mins before your time. The entrance is now from Exhibition Road (see photo) and they will scan your ticket barcode (on your phone or if you printed it out.)
All COVID safe and staff are always helpful if you need it.

Everyone should really go and explore the V&A. Forget about using a map once you’re inside, just get lost and find something new, I always do. Don’t miss the Cast Courts and the Jewellery room as my favourites (also the pottery floor, I won’t tell you where it is, but follow my top tip and you won’t go wrong😉.)

My top tip, take the lift to the top of the museum and work your way down without using a map. You will come across many wonderful things. (Some of the upper floors are closed due to COVID. This includes the lifts at the main entrance)
Beautiful museum filled with so many interesting art from around the world 🤩

Went to the Fashioning Masculinities exhibit and it was beautiful! The rest of the museum is also incredible and  I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to see everything. I also checked out the costume/theatre exhibit and the sculpture gallery and both were incredible!

This is a most wonderful museum where you need to keep going back time and again to see everything. This time we concentrated on the glass gallery, the cast rooms and the modern design sections. The only complaint I have, as ever, is with the cafe facilities here. The queues are long and the tables are always full so if you are on your own queuing for food or just a coffee you have no chance of getting seated once you've got it. It is a nightmare if you are accompanied by young children. There must be a better way.
I wish I'd given the V&A more time, I enjoyed it more than the Tate Modern. Can't wait to come back! Lots of great museums all walking distance from each other.
Booked a ticket for the Faberge Eggs from Russia exhibition,  friendly staff, very clean , café was a bit pricey, amazing place to visit, so much to see , definitely will come back 😀

Mixture of historic, traditional and modern art, the museum have huge exhibits from around the world. Free entry like most of the British museums, you will always find something new to explore that you missed from your earlier visit.

V & A was spectacular as always. Never fails to impress.
We saw the Beatrix Potter Exhibition. Just so charming.

What a refreshing and vibrant place this is.  There is so much to tantalise the senses.  Faberge!  Stunning!  Beatrix Potter, amazing!  From the Theatre and Performance, with the 200 years of the Ballet, so interesting and the stage costumes from great plays and film - the costumes of Sir Lawrence Olivier and Vivien Leigh - so beautifully made and displayed, amongst others.  The staff were also lovely and helpful, especially Nathan M, who was an excellent host.  I would recommend spending several hours here, it has everything in abundance!

It's one of the underrated museums out the great 3 (Natural History, Science, an finally - this one - Art). You never set time apart to see this museum, because it's outshined by it's two siblings. But it's definitely worth it to go there:)
I enjoyed the Asian part of the museum, especially the exhibitions about the Samurai era. It takes 4 hours to go through it. Take your time and do the tour properly:)

Went to see the Alice in wonderland exhibition. It was fantastic to see how it has influenced art, politics and film over the last 100 years.
V&a handled the amount of people well and staff were fantastic as always.
Fantastic place only saw half as huge.really interesting.
Great museum with exhibition on masculinity and clothing through the ages.

Has always been high on my to do list but previously the kids preferred Natural History or Science museums. At last I get to choose and WOW! The building itself is as stunning as the exhibits. I'll be back soon.

The best part of London is its museums and you can visit most of them for free. The museum has an impressive collection of art and sculptures from around the world. The entrance has a fabulous glass chandelier. Not to be missed.

Very beautiful and well kept building both inside and out.
However,  it is very difficult to navigate around and very easy to get lost. The signposting is not very clear and because of this we felt like we were going around in circles, this caused us to give up and leave earlier than planned, and we even had difficulty finding the exit.
The staff here are very helpful and welcoming though

Interesting, even though this is not particularly my kind of museum, walking round for several hours, you will absolutely bump into something that is your thing, if only a small section (for me, the architecture and furniture areas were interesting). Unfortunately, the two main exhibitions of Beatrice Potter and Faberge were sold out so I did not get a chance to visit those, but time was also against me.
Pleasant few hours spent here today, including sketching in they're famous Casts Room
Lovely building, huge area filled with priceless treasures. Easy to book and not too busy.

The crystallization of art is worth visiting more than any museum, and the frequency of visits is about the same every month.  The interior design is particularly unparalleled, the sense of light and shadow, the sense of design, exhibitions, especially clothing and architecture exhibitions, I really like

Absolutely wonderful museum, we visited on our last day before travelling home & unfortunately after 3hrs we still hadn't seen everything. Highly recommend and I will definitely visit again.
Also the coffee dcake from the restaurant was superb.

Absolutely in love with this place definetley in my Top 3 of Museums in London. Huge building with a diverse collection, I was especially impressed by the great ammount statues and the amazing ceramic collection located on the topmost floor. Entry to the permanent collection is free, expect to spend a whole afternoon in there if you want to see everything that has to offer.

A lots of gems. Consecutively, this museum is updated according to seasonal and thematic events. It's amazing that we can visit here for free. You'd better stay tuned with latest news emailed by the musieum. Lastly, your donation to the meusium is appreciated in order that this amazing places lasts for good.

What a great place to go and visit for a few hours. Loved the sculpture gallery as well as the amazing cast court. Hoping to go back to see the various paid exhibitions that are on including the Beatrix Potter art.
What an amazing museum. Such awe inspiring collections and such an awesome building too. A lovely outside cafe in an amazing courtyard. Watch out for the low flying pigeons though! .

We just arrived to London visit the whole exhibition in Friday at about 4-5pm and blondish  girl with glasses was very cheeky with my family. She closed the most important part of the Albert Museum and she didn't let us to look around. In the internet and next to the entrance we saw in Friday the museum is open until 10pm.
You should inform people better about the opening time.
The museum is spectacular!
Another lovely visit to the V and A. Happened upon new areas I've not seen before, and the temporary exhibition was well worth the cost of the tickets.

I thought excellent. Large collections, sculptures great, some are massive. Very helpful staff, enjoyed dance pop up performance. Furniture, Eastern, dresses, budhism. There is so much here that it's too much to try and see all at once. Risk of museum overload.
It is fantastic so much to see off history you need All day to see it all 👍

I recently visited London for a few days and went to look around the 3 major museums including this one, British Museum and Natural History. This one was by far the most interesting. It will easily take half a day to see it in entirety. The 'cast room' is must see due to the scale of the sculptures! (Photo Below)

Awesome place , you can get easily entry ticket, free only, bigger museum , you can see all the arts like asian , European and others, good place to visit, you can visit science museum and this v&a museum same day
It was okay but the experience could be vastly improved with Museum attendants being on hand to explain and discuss the excellent array of art and antiquities displayed.

An overwhelming amount of artifacts in a lovely, FREE museum. So many of the artifacts were so extraordinary that I felt they could have thier own museums. We were there for 3 hours and saw little more than half the museum. A very impressive collection.
A truely amazing experience. Would love to go again, spend about two hours there and really only got to explore about 30-40% of the place
Alice in Wonderland blew my mind. We're all mad here, this exhibition gave me a brand new perspective on the famous line.
Fabulous museum. Although struggled to exit due to works being done
Its always a memorable day out to visit the V&A

Impressive, impressive, impressive, absolutely impressive collection of artworks everywhere from all corners of history. I'm still stunned by the enormous displays of roman monuments in the east courts (see pictures, it reminded me so much of the novel Piranesi by Susanna Clarke, a must-read if you like this place). Plenty of seats to contemplate the displays in comfort, a nice fountain garden in the middle outside, nice caffes and restaurants, even the victorian toilets were admirable! And entrance is free!

An absolute joy to see the variety of human skills  throughout the ages and cultures. Items from intricate carvings from every conceivable material, woven fabrics for fashion and the home and truly magnificent jewelry, gen stones and accessories. It never fails to amaze me what the imagination can produce and all displayed with such care and attention to detail.
The fountain and the cafe are both very nice. My niece who is almost two loves running around in the fountain on her own, so it's great for kids. The cafe is a nice place for lunch or to grab coffee

Me and my friend had travelled to London for the weekend and were both so excited to visit the V&A museum. However upon arrival we were told the cloakroom was closed and that we couldn’t take our small rolling bag in, and the man on the door said that we could queue for the natural history museum cloakroom but it was very long (the tone was very sarcastic and almost rude). There was no apology or accommodation to that.
Loved this day out definitely need more than a day to see it all.
A very interesting place plenty to see I enjoyed the day

Loved everything about te museum. Having watched "inside the Museum" it was a charming to see everything in place and appreciate all that goes on behind the scenes. Will be back to see future themes and obviously in two visits we didn't get to see Everything.

Became a member today and saw two special exhibitions. General admission is free. One exhibition on 'Bags' & 'second exhibition Alice'.(Alice in Wonderland) There is so much to see. There are also workshops & courses too.

Very easy booking system and though long queue for admission very efficiently managed into museum.
Collections really well curated and haven't been "dumbed down" so one has the experience of exploring a real museum.

Great museum!!
We booked our tickets and were worried as we were late but at the entrance they only checked the email  without scanning it or checking the time.
Excellent place to visit. You will need best part of a whole day or at the very least 4 hours. Second floor contains an amazing collection of jewelry and gems.
Great free entry, they had the medieval and renaissance display, that was really interesting.

Victoria and Albert museum is always great to visit. I go there every time I'm in London.

I didn't like Beatrix Potter's exhibition. I love her watercolours and drawings, but unluckily it was too dark inside and impossible to read the explanations and to properly see her drawings and paintings!

The only thing I appreciated were her small books as you could sit down and finally see her paintings printed in the book as there was a spot of light conveniently positioned that allowed the books to be read and the paintings to appreciated!!

Was it worth paying for the exhibition? Not as it was organized....

One of my favourite sculpture museums in london
Easy to get lost in history

A magnificent museum with outstanding exhibits. I love the V&A as I don't think it's 'stuffy' and there is something for everyone there.
Staff were helpful and friendly.
The food in the cafe is superb!

Saw the exhibition for African fashion at the V&A. One of London's iconic cultural and arts venues. Great to see some of Africa's fashion credentials been showcased. The exhibition didn't go far enough in my opinion; but great venue and organisation.

Wow just wow, let me start by saying it's FREE and in this day an age is in on its self an amazing thing. Plain your day well by starting early have cup of tea in there dining room witch was also amazing the ceiling wow then start your journey around the world and time my favourite parts had to be the Japan and the jewellery room, don't have lunch there although everything looks fantastic it comes with a price, go across the street and you will find all of your favourite food outlets and some you don't know. Head back in after because there is no way you got to see it all lol.

Loved the Faberge exhibition. Despite the crowds, I was able to enjoy the intricacies and creativity of the beautiful Faberge pieces as well as the history of Faberge itself and the relationship between the Russian and British royal families. The way the exhibition was curated will be remembered for a long time!

Went most recently for the Curious & Curiouser exhibit. 10 stars. Warning: there will be a long wait for the VR experience- it wasn't to my tastes but I forgot to wear contacts & couldn't see anything without my glasses (learn from my mistakes)! Otherwise it was a brilliant experience. Well worth the price and the hassle of a journey to South Ken.
Amazing experience for a free museum. If you're in London you can't miss it

The museum is absutely stunning!!! A must see when in London! The museum can pride on its huge collections of historical and contemporary arts from Japan to China to Europe to Africa. One won't know where to turn first and will surely take a million of photos. 👍

There are a couple of cafés inside to buy some refreshments. Also, there's a big souvenir shop offering a wide variety of artistic gifts. 🎁

Finally, don't forget to have a sit in its inner courtyard surrounded by flowers 🌺 looking at the large fountain in the middle. When I was there, it was a quite hot summer day, so not only children dipped their feet in it. It was such a relaxing end of my visit. Highly recommend! 🌞
Excellent eclectic collection and super cafe.

You have to plan the sections you want to visit if you have little time.  If the first exhibitions do not interest you, take the time to take the tour because there is something for everyone.  Also, I liked the choice of presentation of objects.
Excellent and delightful exhibition experience - die to the history of the building to appreciating fashion as a significant contribution to art!

Fabulous museum, loved the metal exhibition. Disappointed that it's an extra charge to see the Beatrix Potter exhibition. Lovely café where you can eat and drink your own food. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit
What an absolute treasure of a place...with so much to see! I need to go again to see more! If you are visiting London make this a venue to visit
Had a lovely time at the Alice in Wonderland exhibition, this museum is always a good choice for an interesting few hours

Brilliant brilliant brilliant! We visited the Masculinities exhibition and popped in to see the Buddhism exhibition too. Always a great place to visit.

Note… Eat before or after as the choice can be limited and expensive.

Some good exhibits and much better once you get deeper in & it gets quieter. Entrance and first few rooms are packed and noisy! They had me prebook a ticket online for a timed slot, but on arrival there was no one to show this ticket to, clearly no timeslots being used or monitoring of how many people were inside at one time. Also found the layout really confusing, I definitely didn't see everything there was to see but repeated a lot of areas

Huge museum, not too crowded. Good food and drink facilities. We went for the fashion and theater sections mainly and were a little disappointed at the number of items not on display. Excellent sculpture section.
Enormous collection.  Good place to learn about history.
one of the best museum in London👍🏻

Excellent collections. The courtyard and paddling pool (with a café and bar!) are a haven on a hot sunny day, and a wonderful place to rest after walking around the building. The building itself is beautiful also.

Beautiful oriental art, artifacts and
Marble sculptures.
Beautiful museum. Should book in advance.

Love the V&A. One of the best places in town to see blockbuster exhibitions. The new entrance, on the side of the building, it’s a bit annoying as you arrive, walking from the tube, in front of the old one which was easier to access.
Cafe/food options are average, and I would not bother.

We had travelled to London for a weekend trip and we’re super keen to go to the V&A museum. After travelling to all the way to South Kensington just to visit this museum, we were met by a security guard telling us their cloak room was closed and that we could not enter the museum (we had a carry case). We then asked for a potential alternative place to leave our case as we were so keen to visit to which they sarcastically replied ‘well you could try the natural history museum, but the line is pretty long’. Very disappointed in this visit as no where yesterday did the website clearly label the cloakrooms as out of use.

Amazing place...beautiful architecture and incredible exhibits. I recommend.
I particularly went to see Alice's exhibition but there are a lot of things to see there.

Wow, uau, wwwoooowwww…. Words are not enough to describe the V&A… this place is out of this world! Prepare yourself to walk through time and experience a unique trip! A trip which will take you across all continents to all the corners of the world! Beautiful, simply
Beautiful!!!
menswear exhibit was amazing, well curated and displayed
Magnificent. The permanent exhibition are accessible for free. Focus on design of everyday items. The current exhibition on men's fashion is really worth it's price too. Little gift shop
Nice and historical museum. Beautiful and historic Cafe
Great experience!  There is just too much to see all in one day, worth several visits!

Visited the Alice: Curiouser and Curiouser exhibition and it was wonderful! Plenty to see - we were in there for roughly 2 hours. Only 4* because the room with the VR experience had only two headsets working! Very long wait (up to 30-40 mins). Overall, had a wicked time and would defo recommend.
Beautiful museum With an amazing garden. plenty of interesting things to see on all fools. The building itself is historic which made the experience just that much better.

I visited this place, and was glad I did.
First of all, I went to their restaurant, then I went exploring. Then I saw glass windows of jesus, and his mother Mary which was fab. I also saw some buried knights etc.,
It's a very big place, so plan what you want to see. It takes more than one visit. Also buy a  V& A guide price ; £1.00.
All in All a fab place  to visit. Great for kids.

So much to see, we normally pass by this museum in favour of the other nearby museums, but this time we went to see the Great Bed of Ware and found lots of interesting other things to see. Also there are quite a few tactile exhibits so not just lots of statues and fusty glass cases.
Awesome place...you need the whole day there!! 10 out of 10

Beautiful museum, with some amazing collections. The South Asia rooms are fascinating. Would highly recommend you stop by the restaurant which is beautiful, the mutual on the wall is always a joy to be reminded of.
I saw the majority of exhibitions & all exhibitions I saw were excellent. Would definitely come again if I could. Definitely a recommendation for anyone visiting West London or London in general.

One of THE BEST museums in London.   So much to see and marvel at.  Can never see out all in one visit.
Just fabulous!!!   I look forward to going back

Cannot believe I've lived in England for 6 years and only last week did I finally visit. The preservation in history is amazing. A true glimpse into the past to witness what many of our ancestors went through and how they lived day to day
One of the best museum cafes. Visited the, Beatrix Potter exhibition. Very good insights into her life and of course her paintings are extraordinary.
Well curated labyrinth of antiques and objects from across the world. If travelling break the visit in two days to see the most of the collection.
What amazing collections this museum has acquired! Really need more time next time to dig deeper into it. The huge columns full of intricate carvings were especially impressive.
Needs no introduction - blew my mind again when I decided to visit. One of the most spectacular museums.

A great art collection museum with a lot of incredible masterpieces that can only be found here. Plan to spend your whole day or at least a half day (min 3 hours), otherwise you will not get to see enough. Highly recommend to revisit abd check for exhibition details. Also, you can apply V&A m membership and members can access exhibitions for free.

So about a week or so I went to the V&A Musues, I've not been here for years, it was good and very interesting, I had visited the Alice in Wonderland exitibiton, and what a lovely experience it was, definitely worth a visit, you will be in for a treat 😊

Went to see the Fabergé exhibition which was wonderful. Spent several hours after perusing the museum where we could have spent days- what an extraordinary collection of everything from ancient artefacts through fashion to furniture. Well worth a visit.

user_name: Shazzy's Adventures in Rosie With Smudge
text: I absolutely love this awesome museum! You could easily visit every day for a month and not see everything! Fabulous exhibitions which, as a member, are free!

Amazing place. It is so big that it would take hundreds of hours to see it all. I was fascinated by the cast objects in two large rooms. There were also some explanations of the complicated casting methods used.

A beautiful building with eclectic collections of art, fashion, sculpture, and other pieces of history. A welcome counterpoint to the organised, monothematic collections in other attractions, such as the British Museum. The Victoria and Albert Museum (often abbreviated as the V&A) in London is the world's largest museum of applied and decorative arts and design, as well as sculpture, housing a permanent collection of over 2.27 million objects. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The V&A is located in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in an area known as "Albertopolis" because of its association with Prince Albert, the Albert Memorial and the major cultural institutions with which he was associated. These include the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum, the Royal Albert Hall and Imperial College London. The museum is a non-departmental public body sponsored by the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport. As with other national British museums, entrance is free. The V&A covers 12.5 acres (5.1 ha)[5] and 145 galleries. Its collection spans 5,000 years of art, from ancient times to the present day, from the cultures of Europe, North America, Asia and North Africa. However, the art of antiquity in most areas is not collected. The holdings of ceramics, glass, textiles, costumes, silver, ironwork, jewellery, furniture, medieval objects, sculpture, prints and printmaking, drawings and photographs are among the largest and most comprehensive in the world.

The holdings of ceramics, glass, textiles, costumes, silver, ironwork, jewellery, furniture, medieval objects, sculpture, prints and printmaking, drawings and photographs are among the largest and most comprehensive in the world. The museum owns the world's largest collection of post-classical sculpture, with the holdings of Italian Renaissance items being the largest outside Italy. The departments of Asia include art from South Asia, China, Japan, Korea and the Islamic world. The East Asian collections are among the best in Europe, with particular strengths in ceramics and metalwork, while the Islamic collection is amongst the largest in the Western world. Overall, it is one of the largest museums in the world. Since 2001, the museum has embarked on a major £150m renovation programme. New 17th- and 18th-century European galleries were opened on 9 December 2015. These restored the original Aston Webb interiors and host the European collections 1600–1815. The Young V&A in East London is a branch of the museum, and a new branch in London is being planned. The first V&A museum outside London, V&A Dundee opened on 15 September 2018.

We recently visited the Victoria & Albert Museum (free entrance), choosing to concentrate our efforts mainly on the European [Blue rooms on the V&A Map] Section. By focusing on targeted areas within the museum we were able to enjoy a comprehensive visit, while conserving our energy and not moving around from one end of the museum to the other to see certain highlights.

Starting at the Medieval to Renaissance rooms on Level 0 and 1, as the museum opened at 10am, we proceeded to spend around 90 minutes viewing these gallery rooms as well as the nearby Raphael and Cast Court rooms, showcasing artefacts, sculptures, writings and other items from the Middle Ages, Gothic, Baroque, Renaissance and Rocco periods. Items on display are spaced nicely and just lovely to inspect. Some of the decorative church doorways that have been reconstructed here are remarkable to look at.

We then proceeded upstairs to the Britain galleries (1500-1760AD) on the second floor and (1760-1900AD) on the forth floor, followed by the Sculpture rooms (1300 - 1600AD) found back on the ground floor, near the gift shop. These sections required another 75 minutes to browse. The highlights included the splendid 'Great Bed of Ware’ collection and many of the sculptures seen in the The Dorothy and Michael Hintze Galleries (rooms 21-24).

In the end, we found that concentrating our efforts on a smaller section of the museum had many advantages. We were able to visit sections of the V&A Museum that were most interesting to us personally and spend plenty of time, comprehensively looking over most of the collection in these galleries and rooms. We also didn't feel as tired due to not racing around the entire museum trying to visit selected highlights scattered throughout.

Regardless of how you decide to visit the V&A museum, we highly recommend spending a bit of time getting to know about the museum prior to your visit. This will greatly enhance your experience when you are there. We also highly suggest paying the (£1 donation) and using the V&A brochure map to help navigate your way around. Other helpful tips for how to visit can be found on our previous review for the Victoria and Albert Museum.
