This time I visited the Medieval and Renaissance section. As you can imagine, it's mostly religious art, but fantastic nevertheless. There's some stunning stained glass, some truly intricate artwork on religious items such as Reliquary, candle holder, miniature sculptures, and the pièce de résistance is the "The Boar and Bear Hunt Tapestry". Unmissable.

A great museum covering a wide variety of different art forms. From the classical statues to the periodic exhibitions of the laser spaceships of tommorow, this venue is a lovely space to explore different aspects of the art world. Pick a place to sit and draw the outline of Apolo or just wonder the progress of fashion throughout human history. Theres also a car exhibition you should totally check out.
Ist class all the way. Been to the Victorian. Albert many times and still haven't seen everything. Can't wait for my return visit

Victoria and Albert Museum is one of the great fantastic London museums that you must visit when visiting London.  There's really something for everybody here.  Whether you're interested in Furniture, paintings, ceramics, Arabic, asian. Or you want to visit one of the rotating exhibitions.  I cannot recommend this Museum enough.  It also has wonderful cafes to eat food when you want a break from all the wonderful art.  Keep in mind this place is also huge.  6 floors and three eating areas are intermixed between a lot of Art.

I've been to many museums in the world. The interesting thing about this museum is its breath of history and object. I'm not sure yet but it may become my favorite museum ever visited. Think miniature Hermitage meets the Louvre meets craft.  The website doesn't even give an inkling of how amazing this museum presents.  A must see if you're in London.

Free! and wonderful.
The Raphaels and the Cast Courts were great but the Tipoo's Tiger was the most original piece.

One of London’s top cultural centres. A real asset, as it’s free to the general public.

I was lucky enough to attend the Dior exhibition, which was phenomenal! I thoroughly recommend this exhibition, to anyone interested in fashion and design.

There’s also a treasure hunt you can do via your phone, throughout the building, a fantastic way to discover artefacts, at your own pace.

An amazing experience, starting the moment you get out of the tube station tunnels as the tunnel entrance takes you straight to the first exhibitions, which was quite surprising.
This museum is much more relatable than many I've been to before. It has furniture, fashion, daily use items from different eras around the world. The exhibitions are very nicely designed, whole rooms to fit the theme of different time periods. It paints a really good picture of what life used to be back in the days. Expect to spend the whole day here as there are a lot of collections, entry is free but there are a few paid areas. The outdoor courtyard surrounded by the beautiful old architecture is a perfect spot for lunch and a break from the museum. It was also quite empty even though it was Sunday so if you want to avoid the crowds and queues of the more popular museums such as the natural history or the British museum, Victoria and Albert is definitely a must see.

Wow. This place is Huuuuuuuuuge. So so so so much to see. Every exhibit was well laid out and had detailed information. Great you can take photos. The tea room needs to be seen as it's amazing. I was going to give it one less star as it's very expensive to buy food and drink, £2 for a can of coke but then it is London so it's to be expected and it is free admission.

What a wonderful experience I have got. Victoria and Albert Museum is a must! There is free admission and it is located just next to the Natural History Museum. Would definitely recommend spending a day visiting those places.
Such an interesting museum! Different from the rest in London. Highly recommend a visit

Jaw-dropping selection of artefacts, every corner you turn there's something else to see, lovely tranquil spots to stop inside and out to pause and take it all in. Will need to come again many times to have any chance seeing all. Great gifts in shop too. Definitely 10/10
Nice and free museum. Lovely garden in the middle. Drop in if you are passing by.

There is so much to see at the V&A museum. The museum is predominantly split geographically and by era. There are always different exhibitions going on, both free and paid ones. The building itself is lovely and grand. It's also located right next to the Natural History Museum and Science Museum in case you wanted an extra dose of museum ;) though if you were to truly look at everything at the V&A it'll take a good part of a day and it's a wonderful place to spend time.
Enjoyable trip to the V&A. I haven't been there for decades and came away feeling that it offers an unusual mix of art and history.

Its really big and so much to see and arranged perfectly. I visited this place to see Indian history artifacts and I am amazed and totally satisfied after seeing some very important things.
The most amazing things which i saw was related to The Great Marathi Emperor Chatrapati Shivaji maharaj. Vaghnak and one sward and some other things. Then the Tipusultan tiger and Shaha Jahans wine glass.
Exhibits well presented. Not too busy so much more enjoyable than other South Ken museums.

Grate museum with plenty of rooms and interesting displays.
Much quieter than the rest of the surrounding museums which I is appreciated.
A back garden takes you away from the main road noise.
I have taken 1 star off as the staff are not that great in the main desk. They are pretty much uninterested on queries about the membership.
Stunning as always. This and the natural history museum are jewels in London's museum crown. Please go!

Do not try to see everything in one visit. The V+A is massive and you'll only exhaust yourself. The cafe is beautiful. I'd recommend going for lunch and finding a nice place to sit by the stained glass windows to soak up the atmosphere. The cafe is reasonably priced too with a good selection of hot and cold food.
The cast courts is probably my favourite part of the whole museum. It feels so immersive, especially the inside of Trajan's Column - the perfect place to chill out for a moment.
It would be best to know what your area of interest was before you went as it's very easy to get lost in this museum!

Amazing Museum and admission is free. I've been here multiple times and it's always a different experience. I'm an Advertising and PR student and the V&A is a great place for inspiration. Highly recommend any creatives to visit. The building itself is an amazing piece of work. I would suggest not having bags with you as there's a lot to see. Alternatively you can use the cloakroom. If you've still got energy after your visit head across the road and check out the natural history museum.
One of the best museums in London, always with a new show or three. Also the classics and Dippy is back down the road🙂

The most exciting museum which I ever seen. V&A represents the history of world’s design and arts, housing a permanent collection of over 2 million objects. It was founded in 1850s and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. Also I highly recommend to visit new V&A filial established this year in Dundee, Scotland.

You will never ‘do’ all the V&A in one trip, in fact with everything going on here, and the regular special exhibitions, you can never see all of the V&A, so there is always something to come back for each visit.

A wealth of exhibition spaces, varied objects from many periods and places.you can sit sounds in good weather and take a break.

If I had to pick fault the food offerings could be improved with better value for money - but that’s like most of the museums around this area. Luckily there are plenty of good places around so plan your visit and eat before/after your visit.

I hope you enjoy the V&A as much as I do.

Excellent museum. Love the jewellery exhibit, the minute portraits, the sculptures , textiles... in fact it is an excellent museum with good food.
The central court yard on a sunny day is very nice too.

This is definitely one of my favourite museums, tonnes of great displays, and tonnes of amazing pieces from all over the world. Some very old and important artwork can be found here. Free admission, you only need to pay for certain exhibitions. This would make a great day out with the family with lots of things to look at.
It was Wooow, such a big museum with so much to see. I've spent 2.5 hours and still couldn't see everything. I will definitely be back for more.
Absolute must for history buffs. Visitors from Indian subcontinent would get to see Tipu's Tiger, Ranjit Singh's golden throne. Entry is free.
Great place to visit now. Although only the ground floor and lower level are open. Would have loved to be able to see the exhibitions upstairs.
My absolute favourite museum in London. I could spend all day here. The variance in displays and exhibits kept us interested for hours.

I went for the Christian Dior exhibition so can't comment on the entire establishment. The building itself has some wonderful architecture, mixed with some modern installations, and is accessible from the South Kensington tube station. As soon as you get off the tube, follow the signs for the museum and they'll take you through a cool tunnel to the entrance!
The Dior exhibit was enchanting, curated beautifully, and displays some incredible pieces which mean you can hear a swoon in every room.

Great museum! Loved the variety of things on display. Went in on a late Tuesday afternoon. Not busy at all.

There were people sketching pieces of the art work. It was nice to see. Fun place to eavesdrop. Lots of small groups discussing the signifance of different pieces.

Really loved the special exhibition on video games. I have always been a fan of video games. Seeing some popular titles with their story boards out for show made me appreciate all that goes into creating a new video game world.

Absolutely incredible collection! The place is huge. One of the highlights is the fantastic jewelry collection from ancient pieces to contemporary. I had a great time exploring this place for the afternoon!

Amazing museum with a lot of content of so many different kind. Amazing that this museum (and so many others in London) is free of charge. Great way to both encourage conservation of our common heritage and share it with future generations!

This museum is located on Exhibition Road. The Natural History Museum and the Science Museum are also in the vicinity, so you could do all of them in one trip. I got there by taking the Underground to South Kensington Station and then walking north in the underground tunnel walk-way. Exits to the various museums are clearly signposted.

Entrance to the museum is free but a £5 donation is suggested. This museum is absolutely fantastic. It houses the largest collection of applied and decorative art in the world spanning a period of 5000 years.

There are 3 cafes to help the patron to get through this expansive collection. I would recommend going on one of their free tours. There are over 10 tours, categorized by their subject matter.
Loved it, must see while in London, UK

As usual, a stunning new exhibit from the V&A featuring the house of Dior. Ranging from inception right up to present day we all marvelled at such iconic designs right up close, plus all of the perfume and accessories that come with them. Heaving with crowds of course but for good reason- the attention to detail and the set dressing is simply breathtaking.

Always a must stop while in London towne, the V&A offers four floors of art and sculptures ranging from iron work, stained glasses, jewelry, and pottery to name a few. With free admission and handicap accessible entry, one could spend just a few hours, or the entire day walking around. Seasonal exhibits with entry fees are also available. Depending on the exhibit, tickets may run out, so please show up right at opening to ensure you receive a spot.

There's a lot to see here, you can easily spend hours here even if you're not going into great depths

No advanced tickets required

Excellent selection of years of great british fashion and colonist rampage.
It is massive and cannot possibly do it justice in one visit.
Perhaps one of the few reasons a person may consider moving to London. At least for a short while.
Museum is free of charge.

This is one of my favorite museums! The collections are fascinating. There is so much to see and the building itself is a work of art. Also, I love the café...scones, teas, hot meals... everything I've tried is very tasty. The museum itself is free (as are most in London) so it's a must-see!

Great free to enter museum with paid for special exhibits.

Top tip is go the first floor cast gallery for some comfortable seating and is quiet.
Like all the great museums, the V&A needs numerous visits, but even if only have limited time it's worth to go. Emphasis on the decorative arts it's a constant discovery from room to room.

Stunning museum with an extensive and beautifully displayed collection of decorative arts. The inside is a little bit of a maze, so allow yourself to get slightly lost and enjoy the collections.
Entry is free, special exhibitions require a fee.

I've been ignorant to this museum for a while now, with the NHM and Science museum next door and wow..... What an idiot I've been. This is hands down an amazing museum, not just an arty farty museum for fashion. The V&A has so many cool things to do and see and the courtyard in the middle is a hidden gem of London on a sunny day!

Also when it's too busy elsewhere, the V&A is a cultural hiding place that you can (and I now intend to) visit again and again.

Highly recommend as a Londoner and for visitors.
Had some lovely exhibits, appealing to a great range of interests. There was a lot to take in, but it's definitely worth it. Has good facilities and a bit of a pricey store inside

These are well thought out galleries and the collection is vast. I have been many times and there is always something new to see and discover. The shop used to be a really fantastic collection of unique small designer pieces, there are still some but I do feel the branded typical tourist stuff has taken over a bit recently. Also, I miss the bookshop! The cafe is still amazing though and the scones are still worth visiting for!!!

Fantastic museum for people into historical items from all over the world! It was too big to finish everything in one day and the best thing is that its FREE! Should totally try the carrot cake in the cafe downstairs if you have some time! We went back twice to have the cake lol!
Great museum the menswear temporary exhibition is really worth a visit if you have the time!

I've spent years assuming the V &A was mainly a museum showing clothing collections: this is totally not the case and I wish I'd gone before.
There is a wealth of different items on display and I saw the Fabergé exhibition which was very worthwhile. I can recommend visiting even just for an hour as there is so much to see you'll want to go back.

One of my most favorite traditional (non-high tech/interactive) museums to visit. Be aware that luggage and items can/must be checked for a fee before entering the museum. If you are carrying alcohol, you must unpack it and leave it at the front security desk before putting the rest of your belongings in the baggage check. It's rather bizarre and if you're unprepared for it, you will be digging a bottle of whiskey out from between your knickers and dirty laundry in front of a line of people waiting to get inside. The Garden Cafe is in large, beautiful rooms and a good spot to have a drink and light fare, though the food and drinks are expensive and take a long time of queuing to order and receive. Disappointed to see that the bookstore has mainly generic items that one can purchase anywhere and are not specific to the V&A museum.

This is one of the best museum in London. I spend more than two days to see the museum.

Grate collection. The exibit items are well organizedl and detailed.

The jwelary collection is amezing.

No entry fee. 5£ recommend. Wheelchair accessible.

A fabulous British institution, so many wonderful exhibits and exhibitions, from here and around the world, with so many stories to tell.
This is the second year that I have been gifted a membership, which allows free entry into exhibitions, and use of a very pleasant members room, where one can have have tea, coffee, cakes and other food. Unfortunately they have decided that sandwiches should no longer be on their menu, so if you don't want cake, their are only salads in a box, rather small and not very filling.
Definitely a very nice museum right next to the big boy of London. This was a last minute for us since it was our last day in London.
One of the most interesting museums in London. Easy to get lost there :)
Visited CARS exhibition. Very small exhibition with only 14 cars. Entry fee is £18.  Topics are good but no depth. Nice layout but not worth the entry fee.

One of my favourite places in London!! It inspires me to visit this venue.
The library is one of my favourite places. I’m a regular of the national art library and I have to say, this venue made my dissertation process less miserable.
Excellent place for learning European history! But some parts are too tiny for visitors and it’s risky during COVID-19

Went to see the 'Cars' exhibition.
I'm very sorry but, it's not worth anything like the £18 entry fee they're asking.
A random selection of cars that bear no relation to one another.
Eg. - a very pretty little red Mustang coupé posed under a looped video of the Bullit car chase. Different year, different variant, different colour.
Not even worth it to get out of the rain.
Look around the main museum for free - excellent VFM.

A great place to visit. You can spend hours here and not see everything. Most of the exibits are free, but some you've got to pay for. I went and saw Winnie the Pooh exibit and it was really worth the price of admission. You get to see the original drawings by E. H. Shepard, and see original story drafts by A. A. Milne. Truly spectacular and a must see for any Winnie the Pooh fan

This has to be one of my favorite museams of all time. As a costumer and historian, it provides endless resources for not only Europe but southeast Asia as well. Beautifully kept pieces are not a rarity in this amazing museam.

Visited specifically for the Faberge exhibition. Lots of interesting history captured as well as seeing so many beautiful examples themselves. Access was with timed entry tickets but despite this the layout of the exhibition did not facilitate a seamless flow through of attendees, meaning that there was a queue once through the entry door. A little more thought is needed perhaps when such exhibitions are set out at the planning stage.

What a wonderful museum! There is just so many floors and places and statues and paintings and information boards- my god an entire day spent inside is explore to pretty much only one floor haha! It was an incredibly overwhelming and disorientingly huge yet absolutely lovable building. I loved everything about it. And due to the immense size, the issues in our latest... problems... were well-addressed. I recommend a visit, after all, it is free! Thank you to the V&A team for my absolutely stunning visit.
The museum is in a big and very beautiful building. You can spend all day here if you like art and history. It's national museum so It's free but you can donate some money to the museum.

Visited for the first time ever with the kids, wife and nephew (7, 9, 44 and 18). They weren't happy to go in, but once inside they loved it. All the statues and furniture, the clothing, suits of armour, the paintings. Really amazing!!! Everybody agreed to go in if we only visited one display on one floor but after walking around and seeing what there was to see we pretty much saw all three floors and almost every display.

A truly unique collection of many things British, and many things acquired by the British through their colonial exploits. My favorite spot was the hall of sculptures. Also free, they ask for donation only. They also have a nice library, where silence is the rule. Curiously they don’t allow backpacks yet they have WiFi, so I suppose the idea is you carry your laptop up in your hands from the bag check. They have different rooms dedicated Korea, India, China and many other nations.

Quite simply one of the best and most important museums in the world. A treasure trove of exquisite and priceless objects - all beautifully curated. I love how the V&A only selects the best of objects to make sense of an artistic movement or a specific time in history. The building itself is a work of art and a treat to wander around for as long as you wish. Although their special exhibitions are extraordinary (for which there is a fee), the permanent collection though is just a joy to experience and free of charge. A phenomenal privilege to witness and clearly curated and maintained with love and compassion. Go and experience it - again and again if you can.
Beautiful victorian era museum, as interesting for the history as the exhibits

My favourite place in London. The permanent collection is vast and contains many fascinating pieces, and I have seen many of their special exhibits and they are always very well done.

The special exhibits usually take 1-2 hours to go through. You could spend days exploring the galleries, but it’s fun to go for an hour or two to check out a few areas of particular interest.

The cafe, the garden are also very nice.

Awesome place to spend a day or two. Eclectic mix of collections and a somewhat confusing layout, I got lost in the museum. Beware the special exhibits, some can be expensive and might not be worth it. The current Cars exhibit is not worth the price in my opinion, but the free exhibits are great.

Fascinating museum. Worth a visit just to see the architecture of the buildings themselves but they are filled with amazing displays of artifacts. Spent the whole day there and saw just a small fraction of the whole collection.  Will definitely be back!
Love love it. Great collection very well curated nice staff, worth the visit !
Very big and beautiful place. The orientation of the halls is very confusing. You can walk in the same place several times
Amazing for someone who doesn’t like museum. I actually quite enjoyed my time here. Definitely a must go for tourist. There is no entry fees but a donation is welcomed.

A trip to London is always complete when visiting the Victorian Albert museum. Vast collections which leave the mind in awe and wonder. A must visit for locals and tourists. The best thing about it it is free and in close proximity to Great restaurants.
This place is incredible, even if you don’t pay to get into the special exhibits then the rest is free. There is so much to see. A day isn’t long enough.

First time there despite being a 58 year old English man.  Its a beautiful building. The jewellery and the the Constables make it worth a visit alone. Cafe is great value with excellent tea. However at the moment due to Covid you can't leave suitcases at their left luggage. Our workaround was to leave the suitcase in the left luggage at the science museum just up the road. Also shame that as with so much in the art world  there is funding from Sackler organisation.

Fantastic place to visit , very wheelchair friendly  ( smooth floors,plenty of toilets and lifts  )  Great place to eat food is lovely,  not cheap but delicious. Make sure you pick up a map as museum is massive  , we spent 5 hours there and only covered a quarter  , best decide what you want to see first.

Really interesting museum, it is full up of different historical aspects of of different countries. As you walk in you get to explore a different world and learn about cultural differences. It was really interesting, I learned about different outfits, foods, religions etc… very good place to learn a bit of history

Very enjoyable time at this lovely museum, went to view the excellent Alice in Woderland exhibition. That's sadly no longer on.Such a beautiful building, we are lucky that London has so many of these treasures.
Excellent shop too.

We went to see the Mary Quant exhibition. It was very well put together and we enjoyed our visit. We walked through other parts of the museum which looked very interesting. I'd definitely like to go back and see the rest of the exhibits.

What an amazing museum. It boasts all sorts of artwork, paintings, sculpture, decorative arts, attire collections, photography and it is seemingly endless! It also has a few interactive stations for kids and a lot of seating spaces.

The Christian Dior Designer of Dream exhibition was incredible! The work of each of the six creative directors that the House has seen since Dior’s decade-long tenure is displayed through the maze of rooms. The exhibition showcases the evolution of the phenomenon of the fashion designer and the way they communicate with the women through fashion!

An spectacular place! The staff is very nice,  and there exhibitions are incredible. Just to look at the one about Europe through the years took me about an hour and a half because of all the things to see. Extremely recommended to art and history lovers, specially to those who are into cultures  (exhibitions about Asian art divided into countries.)

A huge and superb collection of art and design, a must see for anyone visiting London.

Given that it is free entry for most of the exhibits on show it is worth making several trips as it is easily reached from South Kensington underground station and focus on one or two specific sections at a time as the amount of items you can see can be a touch over whelming.

Marvelous museum and a must see when visiting London, the collection is varied from historical sites from all over the world. The larger works are exact replicas of some very famous and iconical sculptures such as Michelangelo's David (both the early bronze version as the one every one thinks of). Entrance is free of charge!
So much to see and do! Maurice Broomfield photography exhibition was a particular highlight as was fashion through the ages.
Excellent studio pottery exhibition in the ceramics section, the work of Richard Batterham.  In Room 146.  The film is very interesting.

Alice was a fun and interesting exhibition.  Learned a lot about the history which I found fascinating.

Not as impressed by the Faberge egg exhibition as I had hoped I'd be. Photography in this section prohibited 🚫

If you are a design fan this is the museum for you. There is an immense variety of funiture design on display with insightful free audio commentary from the curators offering insight into each designer and their work. A large collection Rodin's beautiful work is on display and was one of the highlights of my visit. There are also extensive collections of jewellery design and silverware on display. The beautiful V&A building also contains an outside courtyard with a shallow waterfall for children or even older chdren to play in. The courtyard was the perfect end to a fascinating day and a beautiful place to rest after all the walking.

Such a beautiful place of creativity. Even got a video games room!

Shame I didn't go in there. Quite expensive. You should buy a member pass to go in there for free, really worth it. 16 pounds for a visit
90 pounds for membership pass.

Got lots of copies of famous stuff

Must visit museum if you are in London. We just saw a small section of it but it blew our mind away. Collection on Islamic art is superb. Frieda kahlo does take away lime light. Would totally recommend visiting for art and design enthusiasts

Perhaps the best museum in the world. I've been here more than twenty times and yet I've only scratched the surface, with each visit revealing another aspect or gallery. Wonderfully curated with exhaustive collections on every single design topic imaginable. The building itself is one of London's greatest wonders - admire the original terracotta facade from the John Madejski Garden. For new visitors: Take a free tour with one of the extremely knowledgable docents for an overview of the museum's history, unparalleled collection, and mission. For people who live in London and can afford it, consider becoming a member. It quickly pays for itself and gives you unfettered access to the incredible rotating exhibitions, from Kahlo to videogames.
Truly an amazing museum with the greatest collection of decorative arts in the world.

We went to see the Tim Walker exhibition, which was stunning. I didnt have much time to explore the rest of the museum but would go back to spend the day there. The museum shops are packed with lots a wide range of items but prepare to pay high prices. I would highly recommend overall.

So much to see, and quite well curated. Layout wasn't cramped like British Museum. More thought was put into this place. Interactive stuff here and there - tried on a replica of a gauntlet, and a cloak. Wish I had spent more time here, like 2 days instead of 3 hours.

Awesome place to visit. Tons of history to learn about and educate the new generation. The little one enjoyed every part especially the fashion portion. Facilities are always kept to the best possible standards.

The best museum in London and that's a tall order in itself. The museum is focused on design and thats a very broad range to cover from the ming dynasty and the ottoman empire passing by the rainassance and Roman times all the way to modern day pop culture icons and fashion designers. The building of the VA is also a beauty in itself.

One of the finest museums in the world. Awesome collections and majestic building. From Roman statues to a  Hello Kitty toaster and everything in-between. Some engaging permanent galleries, including a great theatre and performance exhibition and stunning jewellery gallery. Not as interactive for children as some museums and a bit dark and gloomy in parts. But well worth a visit.

It's the Louvre of London.   They've got mostly Medieval, Elizabethan and Victorian artifacts on display.

Staff is more rude and powertripping than the French, but you get what you pay for.
Very nice museum. A lot of history.

Free museum so nice to walk around and spend time looking at pieces from ancient to modern. Much is gaudy, but interesting. Beautiful Chihuly chandelier in the lobby worth seeing. Four floors, top floor being ceramics which was a bit disappointing.  Some floors are air conditioned, others are exceptionally hot. There are multiple lifts to each floor if needed, a cafe and restrooms.  Special exhibits require tickets but the rest of museum is free to walk around.

There is no word to explain the glory and beauty of this museum. I would definitely visit again and again. I especially liked the Pink Floyd Exhibit. Overall, the museum is very spacious and very informative. There are over 2 million objects of human creativity and being a passionate art lover myself, I enjoyed it. The gift shop is loaded with various gifts ranging from pins to homeware. Recommending to anyone who is in London, it is a must-visit.

We we're aiming to go into the Natural history museum next door but the queue to get in was crazy long. So we came in here instead. Its a great eclectic mix of all sorts of antiques and paintings and odds n ends.
The casts room with copies of Michelangelo's David etc is great. As with the other big museums entry is free but there are special exhibitions which cost.

This museum has a collection of items people use in life as opposed to just visual arts. Clothes, furniture etc from around the world. It's one of my favorite museums in London. Definitely worth a visit if you're interested in historic daily life and culture.
Amazing! Wow! V&A hits the spot magnificently. My 4 and 7 year old boys were captivated for 3 hours.  Still talking about the trip weeks later. Will go again soon.
It's ok. Place is lovely. But... if u want a small coffee, it's expensive,  gift shop is also very expensive

You never can get enough of this museum. One of the best ones in the world . Each room is a different period in history . Plus they always have a new exhibit going on . It’s a museum that is action pack on learning for children and adults
Great museum, great staff, great restaurant. Special thanks for the didactic descriptions of the items.
Fabulous Faberge exhibition. Not too crowded with timed tickets. Cafe excellent choice and good food. Well organised. Staff efficient.

It has become an excellent museum with visually impressive displays for its wide ranging collection. It focuses on design, its history and contemporary trends. As usual the museum is free, but there are captivating temporary exhibitions that require a ticket (around 15 to 20£).

Excellent History of Handbags exhibition. Access was easy and orderly and there was plenty of space. Cafe area is stunning with great selection of food and drinks. One down point, recommendations on getting there say that access is possible through the tunnel, it was closed with no clear advice on how to best get to the right entrance.

Absolutely amazing. Can’t believe I hadn’t gone earlier. Highly impressive exhibits staffed with knowledgeable people. Highly significant artefacts curated sympathetically which really stole my attention throughout. Wear soft soles, the floor is very hard.
The most unique and most beautiful of London’s Museums. Lose yourself and feed your soul. Amazing gift shops too!
A great spot for anyone interested in art and looking to see a different side to London. Visited the Alice exhibit and was blown away by the VR experience! A must-do
Really good day out- Beautiful building and lots of history. Also a lovely garden with pond great for relaxing and resting your feet ! Made even better by being a free admission.
Awesome way to spend an afternoon.

What can one say about this icon museum - you've to visit it and check out the tea room whilst there - a tad steep but the room is highly decorative and well worth it to just sit and unwind after wandering around...I love it !!
nice place to visit, not only the exhibition but also the building itself, it is definitely a good place and worth to spend sometimes, especially rainy days :)
Love all the temporary exhibitions I've seen so far.
I absolutely love the fashion exhibitions at the museum!!!

Love this place
Full of history
So many attractions
Suitable for all ages and all nations
The building is so beautiful
Cafe is nice but staffs are not fully trained

The photography exhibitions were worth the trip alone. Great day out. Taking 1 star off for a tiny point, the restaurant, while it's beautiful and the food was nice, the layout was complicated and wasn't sure where to pay.
Excellent series of collections, covering multiple cultures and ages. Paid exhibitions well worth the cost. A must see if you’re ever visiting London.

Visited the V and A for the Christian Dior exhibition.  It was one of the most stunningly curated musuem exhibits I have ever seen. The V and A have seriously upped their game in the last few years, very impressive.

Visited specifically to see the 'Cars - Accelerating the modern world' exibition and to attend the lunch talk by Brendan Cormier the curator of the exibition. Whilst entry to the V&A is free (please give a donation) the exibition costs £18, considering the erengy, time effort and cost that goes into delivering these exibitions this has to be good value. Clearly Brendan is no a 'car guy' and the exibition is better for it as his perspective is not blinkered or obsessed by the choice of cars on display; yes there are some interesting choices that make you think, why that car; yes there are a few obvious choices and yes there a few omissions, many might moan that there is no Issigonis mini for instance, but we all know that story as its been told a million times. There are elements of the exibition that betray Brendan's transatlantic heritage but overall the exibition comes together and there are some interesting themes that connect the evolution of the motor industry the broader economic and industrial development during the 20th century. Some fantastic choices of supporting material very appropriate and topical! Well worth a visit!
